column19: This is probably not suitable for an answer in this form, but abbreviations in Russian are interesting and have been studied in depth. Tons of interesting phenomena, e.g.:  (1) homonymous abbreviations, where something gets abbreviated based on proximity to pronunciation of a common word. E.g., ВИКА - Восточно-европейская Инвестиционная Компания (East European Investment Company) get abbreviated unusually because Vika is a short name of Victoria, a common female first name.  (2) Another interesting development of the last 40-50 years is the increased  number of inflected forms of abbreviations which by now are perceived as "normal" non-abbreviated forms. E.g. consider БОМЖ - без определенного места жительства (without permanent residence), a reasonably old abbreviation (from 1950s I'd say):  БОМЖ —> ---  бомж-их-а: (noun) a homeless woman —* бомж-атник: (noun) a homeless shelter —> бомж-ушник: (noun) not entirely sure, but this may have the semantics of being poor —* бомж-ева-ть: (verb) to lead homeless lifestyle —> бомж-еват-ый: (adj) looking like a homeless person etc.  (3) "Telescopic" abbreviations where some words drop the final parts and others drop the initial morphemes, e.g., a very old and established acronym from 1920s: Торгпредство - <Торг>овое <Пред>ставитель<ство> (Foreign Trade Commision)  (4) Multiple spelling variants of abbreviation derived inflections, e.g.:  МГУ - Московский Государственный Университет (Moscow State University): *МГУ*шники  vs. *эм*-*ге*-*у*-шники (MGU students)  Sources: -------------- https://sokr.ru/. <- This site documents many thousands of abbreviations. https://static.freereferats.ru/_avtoreferats/01003354275.pdf https://www.irlc.msu.ru/irlc_projects/library/file.php/6bcc5e2789f6ab7352fa9fbf9d69cf1a.pdf

column19: # Transcription of Foreign Acronyms אונסק״ו  = UNESCO נאט״ו = NATO נאס״א = NASA For the above: Formation: Transcription  # Acronyms which get morphologied :p ## Inflections of Acronyms ### Determined (as in, using a determiner) versions of acronyms בי״ס = בית ספר Translation: School Gloss: House[Singular, Construct] Book Formation: a[0], a[1], b[0]  ביה״ס = בית הספר Translation: The School Gloss: House[Singular,Construct] The-Book Formation: a[0], a[1], b[0], b[1] Note: The clitic ה meaning "the" being present within the acronym is of course intentional here, since that is what differentiates it from the previous one   ### Number/Gender Variants of acronyms בתי״ס = בתי ספר Translation: Schools Gloss: Houses[Plural, Construct] Book Formation: a[0], a[1], a[2], b[0]  בתיה״ס = בתי הספר Translation: The Schools Gloss: Houses[Plural, Construct] The-Book Formation: a[0], a[1], a[2], b[0], b[1]  ## Derivations of Acronyms ### Deriving adjectives concatenatively תנ״ך = תורה נביאים וכתובים  Translation: Tanach, Bible Gloss: Torah Prophets And-Writings  תנ״כי  Translation: Of or related to the Tanach Formation: Tanach + letter Yud to form an adjective   ## Derivation of new words by analyzing an abbreviation as a (Semitic) roots דו״ח = דין וחשבון Translation: Report (noun) Gloss: Law and-Account Formation: 1st letter of Law, 1st letter of And, 1st letter of Account  דיווח  Translation: Report (verb) Formation: Reanalyzing דו״ח to back-form a Hebrew root from it and then create a Pi'eL pattern verb from it  דווח  Translation: Reporter Formation: Reanalyzing דו״ח to back-form a Hebrew root from it and then create a KaTaL pattern noun from it   # ָAcronym by morpheme, rather than by word (common for units) מ״מ = מילימטר Translation: Milimeter Formation: 1st letter of "mili", 1st letter of "meter"  ק״ג = קילוגרם Translation: Kilogram Formation: 1st letter of "kilo", 1st letter of "gram",   קמ״ש = קילומטר לשעה Translation: Kilogram Gloss: Kilometer To-Hour Formation: 1st letter of "kilo", 1st letter of "meter",  1st letter of "hour"  מ״ק = מטר מעוקב Translation: Cubic Meter Gloss: Meter Cubed Formation: 1st letter of "meter",  4th letter of "cubed" Note: The 4th letter of cubed was likely chosen because choosing the 1st letter would result in an identical acronym to "milimeter", and also the 4th letter is the 2nd root letter, so it's a distinctive letter for the word
